THE 1924 HULLABALOO
* * *
THE NEWS-LETTER, The Black,and Blue Jay and the Hullabaloo
are Hopkins publications and are advertised as such. This signifies
that the respective boards, and through them the Hopkins undergraduate body, can be held responsible for the policy as well as the
contents of their paper. With this fact in mind, we feel that the contemplated placing of the advertisements of the 1924 Hullabaloo in
the hands of an advertising agency would be a grave error.
It has been demonstrated that agencies often have other purposes in view besides the pleasing of the public. While there may
be only a possibility that, through an agency, the people of Baltimore
may gain a poor opinion of Hopkins and Hopkins activities, this
possibility is one that should by all means be eliminated.
Other Hullabaloo Boards have accepted offers of local agencies
and met with disastrous results. And past performances have shown
conclusively that the financing of the book without outside help is
entirely within the range of human possibilities. We feel that the
Hullabaloo Business Board is contemplating a bad precedent.

fact. Lee is a sectional hero and
the drama of his life is now playing in a disinterested country."
Without going into the dangerous tangle of sectional prejudices,
we must admit that R. F. S. explains very nicely the current success of "Queen Victoria" in New
York, to say nothing of the sale
of the biographies of such national
heroes as Jefferson Davis, Freiherr
von Shoen, Caleb Cushing, Leopold Auer, Michael Pupin, Edward
Bok and Walter Damrosch.

PROF. MAGOFFIN DEFENDS
CLASSICS
"Latin and Greek Are the Foundation
of Our Education," Former Hopkins Professor Tells N. Y. U. Class

"The student who has had a
classical education is superior to
the student who lacks this advantage," Prof. Ralph Van Deman
Magoffin, head of the Department
of Classics at New York University, told the Heights Freshmen at
the Orientation lecture on "The
Classics."
"The Classics are the foundations of our education. The student
who has had the proper training in
Latin and Greek is bound to succeed. For it teaches the student
to think, to work out things for
himself and enables him to do
things in a more able and pleasant
way." Professor Magoffin cited numerous examples in which the
Classics had been of great aid to
men after their graduation.
Professor Magoffin Also showed
that the Classics Were still of vital
importance by telling of the action
France has taken recently in regard to them, to the effect that
every student in France-must take
a four year course in Latin as well
as two years of Greek. For the
French government realized that
they no longer held the high place
in education which they had before
the great war, and that in order to
regain it, they must restore Latin
and Greek.
"Education may be divided into
three clases, material, sentimental
and real. The material consists in
giving the student just enough
knowledge for him to be able to
earn the 'Almighty Dollar.' But no
notion of materialism has ever survived. The sentimental consists
in permitting the student to choose
what subjects appeal to him, and
to study only these. No young
man educated in this way will succeed, he is bound to be found wanting, when a crises approaches. A
real education in anything ana
everything which is going to give
you the basis of a well balanced education, and the thing necessary to
such an education is-the Classics.
That is why France found it necessary to adopt it. For from the
Classics spring the •Sciences, Philosophy and other subjects."
Topics Include Religion

Professor Magoffin's address
was one of the series of Orientation lectures, which are being given in order to help the freshmen
"find themselves" in University
life. Topics which have been created before include religion, the
library, and the University organization.
Professor Magoffin is a noted
classicist, who is president of the
Archaeological Institute of America and who has lectured widely
in this country and abroad. He is
a well-known writer and formerly
taught in Johns Hopkins University.—N. Y. U. News,

THE 1924 HULLABALOO
* * *
THE NEWS-LETTER, The Black,and Blue Jay and the Hullabaloo
are Hopkins publications and are advertised as such. This signifies
that the respective boards, and through them the Hopkins undergraduate body, can be held responsible for the policy as well as the
contents of their paper. With this fact in mind, we feel that the contemplated placing of the advertisements of the 1924 Hullabaloo in
the hands of an advertising agency would be a grave error.
It has been demonstrated that agencies often have other purposes in view besides the pleasing of the public. While there may
be only a possibility that, through an agency, the people of Baltimore
may gain a poor opinion of Hopkins and Hopkins activities, this
possibility is one that should by all means be eliminated.
Other Hullabaloo Boards have accepted offers of local agencies
and met with disastrous results. And past performances have shown
conclusively that the financing of the book without outside help is
entirely within the range of human possibilities. We feel that the
Hullabaloo Business Board is contemplating a bad precedent.

PROF. MAGOFFIN DEFENDS
CLASSICS
"Latin and Greek Are the Foundation
of Our Education," Former Hopkins Professor Tells N. Y. U. Class

"The student who has had a
classical education is superior to
the student who lacks this advantage," Prof. Ralph Van Deman
Magoffin, head of the Department
of Classics at New York University, told the Heights Freshmen at
the Orientation lecture on "The
Classics."
"The Classics are the foundations of our education. The student
who has had the proper training in
Latin and Greek is bound to succeed. For it teaches the student
to think, to work out things for
himself and enables him to do
things in a more able and pleasant
way." Professor Magoffin cited numerous examples in which the
Classics had been of great aid to
men after their graduation.
Professor Magoffin Also showed
that the Classics Were still of vital
importance by telling of the action
France has taken recently in regard to them, to the effect that
every student in France-must take
a four year course in Latin as well
as two years of Greek. For the
French government realized that
they no longer held the high place
in education which they had before
the great war, and that in order to
regain it, they must restore Latin
and Greek.
"Education may be divided into
three clases, material, sentimental
and real. The material consists in
giving the student just enough
knowledge for him to be able to
earn the 'Almighty Dollar.' But no
notion of materialism has ever survived. The sentimental consists
in permitting the student to choose
what subjects appeal to him, and
to study only these. No young
man educated in this way will succeed, he is bound to be found wanting, when a crises approaches. A
real education in anything ana
everything which is going to give
you the basis of a well balanced education, and the thing necessary to
such an education is-the Classics.
That is why France found it necessary to adopt it. For from the
Classics spring the •Sciences, Philosophy and other subjects."
Topics Include Religion

Professor Magoffin's address
was one of the series of Orientation lectures, which are being given in order to help the freshmen
"find themselves" in University
life. Topics which have been created before include religion, the
library, and the University organization.
Professor Magoffin is a noted
classicist, who is president of the
Archaeological Institute of America and who has lectured widely
in this country and abroad. He is
a well-known writer and formerly
taught in Johns Hopkins University.—N. Y. U. News,
